A purchase agreement, also known as a sale and purchase agreement, is a legally binding contract between the buyer and the seller that transfers ownership of the property from the seller to the buyer. This agreement typically includes details such as the purchase price, payment terms, and any conditions or warranties.
On the other hand, a transfer agreement is a contract that transfers ownership of a property from one party to another, but it does not necessarily involve a sale. This type of agreement is commonly used when the buyer wants to take over the existing mortgage or loan on the property, or when the seller wants to transfer the property to the buyer without selling it.
In the context of buying a second-hand house, it is generally recommended to sign a purchase agreement rather than a transfer agreement. This is because a purchase agreement provides more legal protections for the buyer, such as the right to inspect the property before purchase and the ability to negotiate the purchase price. Additionally, a purchase agreement can help ensure that the buyer is not liable for any existing debts or liabilities on the property.
However, if the buyer wants to take over the existing mortgage or loan on the property, a transfer agreement may be more appropriate. This type of agreement can help the buyer avoid taking on the existing debt and can provide more flexibility in terms of the payment schedule and interest rate.
In terms of legal basis, both purchase agreements and transfer agreements are governed by the Contract Law of the People's Republic of China. Specifically, Article 126 of the Contract Law provides that a contract for the transfer of ownership of a property must be in writing and signed by both parties.
